title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. To be insured for an RRB annuity, a worker must generally have at least 10 years of covered railroad work. The family of an insured railroad worker receives RRB annuities equal to or greater than Social Security benefits. If a worker does not qualify for an RRB annuity, their railroad work counts toward Social Security benefits. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement benefits for railroad workers. RRB annuities consist of tier I and tier II amounts, with tier I equivalent to Social Security benefits and tier II based solely on covered railroad service. Surviving spouses may receive widow or widower annuities from RRB, which are generally higher than Social Security benefits due to tier II amounts. The Railroad Retirement Board administers retirement benefits for railroad workers, including tier I and tier II amounts. Surviving spouses may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age, with additional provisions for widows and widowers caring for a deceased worker's child. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widows and widowers. Other provisions in the 2001 law include investment options for retirement funds and adjustments to early retirement reductions. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widows and widowers by adding a new guaranty amount. This new rule applies to all widow(er)s who receive annuities starting in February 2002 or later, and some who began receiving annuities before that date. The total initial minimum amount after the 2001 law is 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts the employee would have received at the time the widow(er) begins to receive an annuity. The widow(er)'s annuity consists of tier I and regular tier II amounts, which increase annually based on the Social Security COLA. The guaranty amount offsets the COLA increase, keeping the total monthly annuity constant for several years. Once the guaranty amount reaches zero, the widow(er) will see an increase in their total monthly annuity as tier I and regular tier II amounts continue to rise. In 2001, changes to widow(er) annuities resulted in higher average monthly payments. A hypothetical widow under prior law would receive $1,150 per month, while under current law, the initial minimum amount is $1,300 per month. This includes tier I and tier II amounts, with the tier II annuity composed of a regular amount and a guaranty amount. The guaranty amount offsets COLA increases until it reaches zero, at which point the total monthly annuity will increase as tier I and regular tier II amounts continue to rise. The widow's total annuity amount is $150 more than under prior law due to the addition of the guaranty amount. Her total annuity will not increase from 2006 to 2012, but the components change yearly. The widow's tier I amount increases by $23 in 2007, while her regular tier II amount increases by $1. The guaranty amount decreases by $24 annually, resulting in a total tier II annuity of $277 in 2007. The widow's total monthly annuity increases due to COLAs starting in 2012, with the guaranty amount gradually decreasing to zero. Her annuity under current law is $1,323 in 2012, higher than the $1,300 under prior law. The differences between current and prior law are shown in Figure 1. Under prior law, her monthly annuity in 2006 would have been $1,150, while under current law, it includes a guaranty amount of $150. The widow's annuity increases due to COLAs starting in 2012, with the guaranty amount gradually decreasing to zero. Her total annuity in 2006 is $1,300, including a $150 guaranty amount.
